statement:
Let $(D,\,+,\,\cdot)$ be an integral domain, i.e. a commutative ring
with non-zero unity 1 and no zero divisors. All non-zero elements of $D$
have the same in the additive group $(D,\,+)$.

[*Proof.*]{} Let $a$ be arbitrary non-zero element. Any $na$ may be
written as
$$na = n(1a) = \underbrace{1a+1a+\cdots+1a}_{n} = (\underbrace{1+1+\cdots+1}_{n})a = (n1)a.$$
Thus, because $a \ne 0$ and there are no zero divisors, an equation
$na = 0$ is with the equation $n1 = 0$. So $a$ must have the same as the
unity of $D$.

**Note.** The of the unity element is the of the integral domain, which
is 0 or a positive prime number.
names: orders of elements in integral domain
